message.content: Look at several existing conjecture .lean files in /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/ to understand the conventions and patterns used. Read at least 3-4 different ones, especially ones that involve set theory or combinatorics. I need to understand: import patterns, how conjectures are stated, naming conventions, and any common patterns. Report back with full contents of the files you read.

content.text: I'll read several conjecture files to understand the conventions and patterns used. Let me start by reading a few of them.

content.content:
1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’
     5â†’open SimpleGraph Finset
     6â†’
     7â†’/--
     8â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #24 (Proved by Grzesik [Gr12] and Hatami-Hladky-KrÃ¡l-Norine-Razborov [HHKNR13]):
     9â†’Every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices contains at most n^5 copies of C_5.
    10â†’
    11â†’We count labeled 5-cycles: injective functions f : Fin 5 â†’ Fin (5n) such that
    12â†’f(i) is adjacent to f((i+1) mod 5) for all i. Each unordered C_5 yields exactly
    13â†’10 labeled 5-cycles (5 rotations Ã— 2 reflections), so the labeled count bound is 10 Â· n^5.
    14â†’-/
    15â†’theorem erdos_problem_24 :
    16â†’    âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin (5 * n))) (h : DecidableRel G.Adj),
    17â†’    haveI := h
    18â†’    G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
    19â†’    (Finset.univ.filter (fun (f : Fin 5 â†’ Fin (5 * n)) =>
    20â†’      Function.Injective f âˆ§
    21â†’      âˆ€ i : Fin 5, G.Adj (f i) (f (i + 1)))).card
    22â†’    â‰¤ 10 * n ^ 5 :=
    23â†’  sorry
    24â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Card
     3â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.GCDMonoid.Finset
     4â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.GCDMonoid.Nat
     5â†’
     6â†’open Finset
     7â†’
     8â†’open scoped Classical
     9â†’
    10â†’/-
    11â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #27 (Disproved).
    12â†’
    13â†’An Îµ-almost covering system is a set of congruences aáµ¢ (mod náµ¢) for distinct
    14â†’moduli nâ‚ < â‹¯ < nâ‚– such that the natural density of integers satisfying none
    15â†’of them is at most Îµ.
    16â†’
    17â†’ErdÅ‘s asked: is there a constant C > 1 such that for every Îµ > 0 and N â‰¥ 1,
    18â†’there is an Îµ-almost covering system with N â‰¤ nâ‚ < â‹¯ < nâ‚– â‰¤ CN?
    19â†’
    20â†’This was disproved by Filaseta, Ford, Konyagin, Pomerance, and Yu (2007).
    21â†’We formalize the negation (the proved result).
    22â†’-/
    23â†’
    24â†’/-- A congruence system has distinct moduli if no two pairs share the same modulus. -/
    25â†’def Erdos27.hasDistinctModuli (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : Prop :=
    26â†’  S.card = (S.image Prod.snd).card
    27â†’
    28â†’/-- The LCM of all moduli in a congruence system. -/
    29â†’noncomputable def Erdos27.systemLcm (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : â„• :=
    30â†’  (S.image Prod.snd).lcm id
    31â†’
    32â†’/-- The density of uncovered integers for a congruence system,
    33â†’    measured as the proportion of integers in {0, â€¦, L-1} not covered
    34â†’    by any congruence, where L = lcm of all moduli. -/
    35â†’noncomputable def Erdos27.uncoveredDensity (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : â„ :=
    36â†’  let L := Erdos27.systemLcm S
    37â†’  ((Finset.range L).filter (fun x =>
    38â†’    âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, Â¬((â†‘p.2 : â„¤) âˆ£ (â†‘x - p.1)))).card / (L : â„)
    39â†’
    40â†’theorem erdos_problem_27 :
    41â†’    Â¬ âˆƒ C : â„, C > 1 âˆ§
    42â†’      âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’
    43â†’      âˆ€ N : â„•, N â‰¥ 1 â†’
    44â†’      âˆƒ S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•),
    45â†’        Erdos27.hasDistinctModuli S âˆ§
    46â†’        S.Nonempty âˆ§
    47â†’        (âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, p.2 â‰¥ 2) âˆ§
    48â†’        (âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, N â‰¤ p.2 âˆ§ (p.2 : â„) â‰¤ C * N) âˆ§
    49â†’        Erdos27.uncoveredDensity S â‰¤ Îµ :=
    50â†’  sorry
    51â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Set.Finite.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     5â†’
     6â†’open Classical Filter
     7â†’
     8â†’/-- The sumset `A + B`: the set of all `a + b` with `a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B`. -/
     9â†’def sumset31 (A B : Set â„•) : Set â„• := {n : â„• | âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ b âˆˆ B, n = a + b}
    10â†’
    11â†’/-- A set `B âŠ† â„•` has natural density zero if
    12â†’    `|B âˆ© {0, â€¦, N-1}| / N â†’ 0` as `N â†’ âˆ`. -/
    13â†’def HasNaturalDensityZero (B : Set â„•) : Prop :=
    14â†’  âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’ âˆƒ Nâ‚€ : â„•, âˆ€ N : â„•, N â‰¥ Nâ‚€ â†’
    15â†’    (((Finset.range N).filter (Â· âˆˆ B)).card : â„) / (N : â„) < Îµ
    16â†’
    17â†’/--
    18â†’**ErdÅ‘s Problem #31** (ErdÅ‘sâ€“Straus, proved by Lorentz [Lo54]):
    19â†’
    20â†’Given any infinite set $A \subset \mathbb{N}$, there exists a set $B \subseteq \mathbb{N}$
    21â†’of natural density $0$ such that $A + B$ contains all except finitely many natural numbers.
    22â†’-/
    23â†’theorem erdos_problem_31 (A : Set â„•) (hA : A.Infinite) :
    24â†’    âˆƒ B : Set â„•, HasNaturalDensityZero B âˆ§
    25â†’      Set.Finite {n : â„• | n âˆ‰ sumset31 A B} :=
    26â†’  sorry
    27â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient
     2â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.Deriv.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’
     5â†’open Nat Finset Filter Set Classical
     6â†’
     7â†’/-- Count of natural numbers n in {1, ..., N} with Ï†(n) < c Â· n -/
     8â†’noncomputable def totientDensityCount (c : â„) (N : â„•) : â„• :=
     9â†’  ((Finset.range (N + 1)).filter (fun n => 0 < n âˆ§ (Nat.totient n : â„) < c * â†‘n)).card
    10â†’
    11â†’/--
    12â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #50:
    13â†’Schoenberg proved that for every c âˆˆ [0,1] the natural density of
    14â†’{n âˆˆ â„• : Ï†(n) < cn} exists. Let this density be denoted by f(c).
    15â†’Is it true that there are no x such that f'(x) exists and is positive?
    16â†’
    17â†’ErdÅ‘s proved the distribution function f is purely singular.
    18â†’-/
    19â†’theorem erdos_problem_50_conjecture :
    20â†’    âˆ€ f : â„ â†’ â„,
    21â†’      (âˆ€ c âˆˆ Icc (0 : â„) 1,
    22â†’        Tendsto (fun N : â„• => (totientDensityCount c N : â„) / â†‘N) atTop (nhds (f c))) â†’
    23â†’      âˆ€ x d : â„, HasDerivAt f d x â†’ d â‰¤ 0 :=
    24â†’  sorry
    25â†’

content.text: Great! Let me read a few more to get a better sense of the patterns, especially some with combinatorics and set theory themes.

content.content:
1â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Archimedean
     3â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat
     5â†’
     6â†’open Classical Finset BigOperators
     7â†’
     8â†’noncomputable section
     9â†’
    10â†’/-- The sumset A + B: the set of all a + b with a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B. -/
    11â†’def sumset35 (A B : Set â„•) : Set â„• := {n : â„• | âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ b âˆˆ B, n = a + b}
    12â†’
    13â†’/-- Schnirelmann density of a set A âŠ† â„•:
    14â†’    d_s(A) = inf_{N â‰¥ 1} |A âˆ© {1, â€¦, N}| / N -/
    15â†’noncomputable def schnirelmannDensity (A : Set â„•) : â„ :=
    16â†’  sInf {x : â„ | âˆƒ N : â„•, N â‰¥ 1 âˆ§ x = ((Icc 1 N).filter (Â· âˆˆ A)).card / (N : â„)}
    17â†’
    18â†’/-- A set B âŠ† â„• is an additive basis of order k if every natural number
    19â†’    can be written as a sum of exactly k elements from B (with repetition).
    20â†’    Since 0 âˆˆ B is assumed separately, "exactly k" is equivalent to "at most k". -/
    21â†’def IsAdditiveBasis35 (B : Set â„•) (k : â„•) : Prop :=
    22â†’  âˆ€ n : â„•, âˆƒ f : Fin k â†’ â„•, (âˆ€ i, f i âˆˆ B) âˆ§ âˆ‘ i, f i = n
    23â†’
    24â†’/--
    25â†’**ErdÅ‘s Problem #35** (Proved):
    26â†’
    27â†’Let B âŠ† â„• be an additive basis of order k with 0 âˆˆ B. Is it true that for every
    28â†’A âŠ† â„• we have d_s(A + B) â‰¥ Î± + Î±(1 - Î±)/k, where Î± = d_s(A) is the
    29â†’Schnirelmann density?
    30â†’
    31â†’This was proved by PlÃ¼nnecke [Pl70], who showed the stronger inequality
    32â†’d_s(A + B) â‰¥ Î±^{1-1/k}, as observed by Ruzsa.
    33â†’-/
    34â†’theorem erdos_problem_35
    35â†’    (A B : Set â„•) (k : â„•) (hk : k â‰¥ 1)
    36â†’    (hB : IsAdditiveBasis35 B k) (h0 : (0 : â„•) âˆˆ B) :
    37â†’    let Î± := schnirelmannDensity A
    38â†’    schnirelmannDensity (sumset35 A B) â‰¥ Î± + Î± * (1 - Î±) / (k : â„) :=
    39â†’  sorry
    40â†’
    41â†’end
    42â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic
     2â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum
     3â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Ordinal
     4â†’
     5â†’open Ordinal Cardinal
     6â†’
     7â†’noncomputable section
     8â†’
     9â†’/-!
    10â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #70
    11â†’
    12â†’Let ğ”  be the cardinality of the continuum, Î² be any countable ordinal, and
    13â†’2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰. Is it true that ğ”  â†’ (Î², n)Â²â‚ƒ?
    14â†’
    15â†’That is, for every 2-coloring of the 3-element increasing sequences of
    16â†’ordinals below ğ” , there is either a homogeneous set of order type Î² for
    17â†’one color, or a homogeneous set of size n for the other color.
    18â†’
    19â†’ErdÅ‘s and Rado proved that ğ”  â†’ (Ï‰ + n, 4)Â²â‚ƒ for any 2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰.
    20â†’
    21â†’Tags: graph theory, ramsey theory, set theory
    22â†’-/
    23â†’
    24â†’/-- The ordinal partition relation `Î± â†’ (Î², Î³)Â²â‚ƒ`:
    25â†’for every 2-coloring of increasing triples from ordinals below `Î±`,
    26â†’there is either a homogeneous set of order type `Î²` for color 0,
    27â†’or a homogeneous set of order type `Î³` for color 1.
    28â†’
    29â†’A homogeneous set of order type `Î´` is given by a strictly increasing
    30â†’function `g` mapping ordinals below `Î´` to ordinals below `Î±`, such that
    31â†’all increasing triples in the image of `g` receive the same color. -/
    32â†’def OrdinalPartition3_2 (Î± Î² Î³ : Ordinal) : Prop :=
    33â†’  âˆ€ f : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal â†’ Ordinal â†’ Fin 2,
    34â†’    (âˆƒ g : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal,
    35â†’      (âˆ€ i j, i < Î² â†’ j < Î² â†’ i < j â†’ g i < g j) âˆ§
    36â†’      (âˆ€ i, i < Î² â†’ g i < Î±) âˆ§
    37â†’      âˆ€ i j k, i < j â†’ j < k â†’ k < Î² â†’ f (g i) (g j) (g k) = 0) âˆ¨
    38â†’    (âˆƒ g : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal,
    39â†’      (âˆ€ i j, i < Î³ â†’ j < Î³ â†’ i < j â†’ g i < g j) âˆ§
    40â†’      (âˆ€ i, i < Î³ â†’ g i < Î±) âˆ§
    41â†’      âˆ€ i j k, i < j â†’ j < k â†’ k < Î³ â†’ f (g i) (g j) (g k) = 1)
    42â†’
    43â†’/--
    44â†’**ErdÅ‘s Problem #70** [Er87]:
    45â†’
    46â†’Let ğ”  be the cardinality of the continuum (viewed as an initial ordinal),
    47â†’Î² be any countable ordinal, and 2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰. Is it true that ğ”  â†’ (Î², n)Â²â‚ƒ?
    48â†’-/
    49â†’theorem erdos_problem_70 (Î² : Ordinal) (hÎ² : Î².card â‰¤ â„µâ‚€)
    50â†’    (n : â„•) (hn : 2 â‰¤ n) :
    51â†’    OrdinalPartition3_2 (Cardinal.continuum.ord) Î² (â†‘n) :=
    52â†’  sorry
    53â†’
    54â†’end
    55â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’
     5â†’open SimpleGraph
     6â†’
     7â†’noncomputable section
     8â†’
     9â†’/-!
    10â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #79
    11â†’
    12â†’We say G is *Ramsey size linear* if R(G,H) â‰ª m for all graphs H with m edges
    13â†’and no isolated vertices.
    14â†’
    15â†’Are there infinitely many graphs G which are not Ramsey size linear but such
    16â†’that all of its proper subgraphs are?
    17â†’
    18â†’Asked by ErdÅ‘s, Faudree, Rousseau, and Schelp [EFRS93].
    19â†’Proved by Wigderson [Wi24]. Kâ‚„ is the only explicitly known example.
    20â†’-/
    21â†’
    22â†’/-- `IsSubgraphOf H G` means H is isomorphic to a subgraph of G: there exists an
    23â†’    injection from V(H) to V(G) that preserves adjacency. -/
    24â†’def IsSubgraphOf {Î± Î² : Type*} (H : SimpleGraph Î±) (G : SimpleGraph Î²) : Prop :=
    25â†’  âˆƒ f : Î± â†’ Î², Function.Injective f âˆ§ âˆ€ u v, H.Adj u v â†’ G.Adj (f u) (f v)
    26â†’
    27â†’/-- The Ramsey property: every 2-coloring of K_n contains G in one color or H in the
    28â†’    other. A 2-coloring of K_n is a graph S on Fin n; one color class is S and the
    29â†’    other is Sá¶œ (the complement). -/
    30â†’def RamseyProp {p q : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q))
    31â†’    (n : â„•) : Prop :=
    32â†’  âˆ€ S : SimpleGraph (Fin n), IsSubgraphOf G S âˆ¨ IsSubgraphOf H Sá¶œ
    33â†’
    34â†’/-- A graph has no isolated vertices if every vertex has at least one neighbor. -/
    35â†’def NoIsolatedVertices {q : â„•} (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)) : Prop :=
    36â†’  âˆ€ v : Fin q, âˆƒ w : Fin q, H.Adj v w
    37â†’
    38â†’/-- A graph G is Ramsey size linear if there exists C > 0 such that for every graph H
    39â†’    with no isolated vertices, the Ramsey property R(G,H) holds at some n â‰¤ C Â· |E(H)|. -/
    40â†’def IsRamseySizeLinear {p : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)) : Prop :=
    41â†’  âˆƒ C : â„, C > 0 âˆ§ âˆ€ (q : â„•) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)) [DecidableRel H.Adj],
    42â†’    NoIsolatedVertices H â†’
    43â†’    âˆƒ n : â„•, (n : â„) â‰¤ C * (H.edgeFinset.card : â„) âˆ§ RamseyProp G H n
    44â†’
    45â†’/-- **ErdÅ‘s Problem #79**: There exist infinitely many graphs which are not Ramsey
    46â†’    size linear but all of whose proper subgraphs are. A graph H is a proper subgraph
    47â†’    of G if H embeds into G (as a subgraph) but G does not embed into H. -/
    48â†’theorem erdos_conjecture_79 :
    49â†’    âˆ€ N : â„•, âˆƒ (p : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)),
    50â†’      p â‰¥ N âˆ§
    51â†’      Â¬ IsRamseySizeLinear G âˆ§
    52â†’      âˆ€ (q : â„•) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)),
    53â†’        IsSubgraphOf H G â†’
    54â†’        Â¬ IsSubgraphOf G H â†’
    55â†’        IsRamseySizeLinear H := by
    56â†’  sorry
    57â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Floor.Defs
     7â†’
     8â†’open SimpleGraph Finset Real
     9â†’
    10â†’/-- Count edges in the induced subgraph on vertex set S:
    11â†’    the number of pairs {u, v} with u, v âˆˆ S, u < v, and G.Adj u v. -/
    12â†’def inducedEdgeCount {n : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    13â†’    (S : Finset (Fin n)) : â„• :=
    14â†’  ((S Ã—Ë¢ S).filter (fun p => p.1 < p.2 âˆ§ G.Adj p.1 p.2)).card
    15â†’
    16â†’/--
    17â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #88 (Proved by Kwan, Sah, Sauermann, Sawhney [KSSS22]):
    18â†’For any Îµ > 0 there exists Î´ = Î´(Îµ) > 0 such that if G is a graph on n vertices
    19â†’with no independent set or clique of size â‰¥ Îµ log n then G contains an induced
    20â†’subgraph with exactly m edges for all m â‰¤ Î´nÂ².
    21â†’
    22â†’Conjectured by ErdÅ‘s and McKay.
    23â†’-/
    24â†’theorem erdos_problem_88 :
    25â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’
    26â†’      âˆƒ Î´ : â„, Î´ > 0 âˆ§
    27â†’        âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) (h : DecidableRel G.Adj),
    28â†’          haveI := h
    29â†’          G.CliqueFree âŒˆÎµ * Real.log nâŒ‰â‚Š â†’
    30â†’          Gá¶œ.CliqueFree âŒˆÎµ * Real.log nâŒ‰â‚Š â†’
    31â†’          âˆ€ m : â„•, (m : â„) â‰¤ Î´ * (n : â„) ^ 2 â†’
    32â†’            âˆƒ S : Finset (Fin n), inducedEdgeCount G S = m :=
    33â†’  sorry
    34â†’

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have a comprehensive set of examples to analyze. Here's my report on the conventions and patterns used in the ErdÅ‘s conjecture files:

## Summary of Conventions and Patterns in ErdÅ‘s Conjecture Files

### **1. Import Patterns**

The files use imports from Mathlib4, carefully selecting only what's needed. Common patterns include:

- **Graph Theory**: `import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic`, `import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique`
- **Set Theory/Cardinals**: `import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic`, `import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum`
- **Finite Sets**: `import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic`, `import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Card`
- **Numbers**: `import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic`, `import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient`, `import Mathlib.Algebra.GCDMonoid.Nat`
- **Algebraic Operations**: `import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic`
- **Analysis**: `import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic`, `import Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.Deriv.Basic`
- **Logic**: `open Classical Filter` (often with `open scoped Classical`)

### **2. How Conjectures Are Stated**

The main theorem statement follows a consistent pattern:

```lean
theorem erdos_problem_NUMBER :
    <logical statement involving quantifiers and hypotheses> :=
  sorry
```

**Key features:**
- Uses full formal logical statements with explicit quantifiers (`âˆ€`, `âˆƒ`)
- May include helper definitions for complex concepts
- Ends with `sorry` (a proof placeholder)
- If disproved, the conjecture is negated: `theorem erdos_problem_27 : Â¬ âˆƒ C : ...`

### **3. Naming Conventions**

**Theorem names:** 
- `erdos_problem_NUMBER` or `erdos_conjecture_NUMBER`
- Uses snake_case

**Definition names:**
- Prefixed with the problem number when problem-specific: `Erdos27.hasDistinctModuli`, `Erdos27.systemLcm`, `Erdos27.uncoveredDensity`
- Descriptive names matching mathematical concepts: `sumset35`, `schnirelmannDensity`, `IsAdditiveBasis35`, `OrdinalPartition3_2`

**Helper definitions:**
- Start with `def` or `noncomputable def`
- Include documentation with `/-....-/` comments
- Use camelCase for definition names

### **4. Documentation Patterns**

Each file includes detailed documentation:

**File-level comments** (top of file):
```lean
/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #NUMBER

[Problem description in mathematical notation]
-/
```

OR (using double-dash format):
```lean
/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #NUMBER (Status: Proved/Disproved/Conjectured by Author):
[Description]
-/
```

**Definition-level comments:**
```lean
/-- Brief description of what this definition represents or does. -/
def myDefinition : SomeType := ...
```

### **5. Common Structural Patterns**

**Noncomputable sections:**
```lean
noncomputable section
  [definitions and theorems]
end
```
Used when dealing with real numbers, cardinality, density, etc.

**Open statements:**
- `open SimpleGraph Finset` - for graph theory problems
- `open Ordinal Cardinal` - for set theory problems
- `open Classical Filter` - for classical logic and limit arguments

**Let bindings in theorems:**

```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic

open SimpleGraph Finset

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #24 (Proved by Grzesik [Gr12] and Hatami-Hladky-KrÃ¡l-Norine-Razborov [HHKNR13]):
Every triangle-free graph on 5n vertices contains at most n^5 copies of C_5.

We count labeled 5-cycles: injective functions f : Fin 5 â†’ Fin (5n) such that
f(i) is adjacent to f((i+1) mod 5) for all i. Each unordered C_5 yields exactly
10 labeled 5-cycles (5 rotations Ã— 2 reflections), so the labeled count bound is 10 Â· n^5.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_24 :
    âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin (5 * n))) (h : DecidableRel G.Adj),
    haveI := h
    G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
    (Finset.univ.filter (fun (f : Fin 5 â†’ Fin (5 * n)) =>
      Function.Injective f âˆ§
      âˆ€ i : Fin 5, G.Adj (f i) (f (i + 1)))).card
    â‰¤ 10 * n ^ 5 :=
  sorry
```

```lean
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Card
import Mathlib.Algebra.GCDMonoid.Finset
import Mathlib.Algebra.GCDMonoid.Nat

open Finset

open scoped Classical

/-
ErdÅ‘s Problem #27 (Disproved).

An Îµ-almost covering system is a set of congruences aáµ¢ (mod náµ¢) for distinct
moduli nâ‚ < â‹¯ < nâ‚– such that the natural density of integers satisfying none
of them is at most Îµ.

ErdÅ‘s asked: is there a constant C > 1 such that for every Îµ > 0 and N â‰¥ 1,
there is an Îµ-almost covering system with N â‰¤ nâ‚ < â‹¯ < nâ‚– â‰¤ CN?

This was disproved by Filaseta, Ford, Konyagin, Pomerance, and Yu (2007).
We formalize the negation (the proved result).
-/

/-- A congruence system has distinct moduli if no two pairs share the same modulus. -/
def Erdos27.hasDistinctModuli (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : Prop :=
  S.card = (S.image Prod.snd).card

/-- The LCM of all moduli in a congruence system. -/
noncomputable def Erdos27.systemLcm (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : â„• :=
  (S.image Prod.snd).lcm id

/-- The density of uncovered integers for a congruence system,
    measured as the proportion of integers in {0, â€¦, L-1} not covered
    by any congruence, where L = lcm of all moduli. -/
noncomputable def Erdos27.uncoveredDensity (S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•)) : â„ :=
  let L := Erdos27.systemLcm S
  ((Finset.range L).filter (fun x =>
    âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, Â¬((â†‘p.2 : â„¤) âˆ£ (â†‘x - p.1)))).card / (L : â„)

theorem erdos_problem_27 :
    Â¬ âˆƒ C : â„, C > 1 âˆ§
      âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’
      âˆ€ N : â„•, N â‰¥ 1 â†’
      âˆƒ S : Finset (â„¤ Ã— â„•),
        Erdos27.hasDistinctModuli S âˆ§
        S.Nonempty âˆ§
        (âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, p.2 â‰¥ 2) âˆ§
        (âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, N â‰¤ p.2 âˆ§ (p.2 : â„) â‰¤ C * N) âˆ§
        Erdos27.uncoveredDensity S â‰¤ Îµ :=
  sorry
```

```lean
import Mathlib.Data.Set.Finite.Basic

/-- The sumset `A + B`: the set of all `a + b` with `a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B`. -/
def sumset31 (A B : Set â„•) : Set â„• := {n : â„• | âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ b âˆˆ B, n = a + b}

/-- A set `B âŠ† â„•` has natural density zero if
    `|B âˆ© {0, â€¦, N-1}| / N â†’ 0` as `N â†’ âˆ`. -/
def HasNaturalDensityZero (B : Set â„•) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’ âˆƒ Nâ‚€ : â„•, âˆ€ N : â„•, N â‰¥ Nâ‚€ â†’
    (((Finset.range N).filter (Â· âˆˆ B)).card : â„) / (N : â„) < Îµ

/--
**ErdÅ‘s Problem #31** (ErdÅ‘sâ€“Straus, proved by Lorentz [Lo54]):

Given any infinite set $A \subset \mathbb{N}$, there exists a set $B \subseteq \mathbb{N}$
of natural density $0$ such that $A + B$ contains all except finitely many natural numbers.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_31 (A : Set â„•) (hA : A.Infinite) :
    âˆƒ B : Set â„•, HasNaturalDensityZero B âˆ§
      Set.Finite {n : â„• | n âˆ‰ sumset31 A B} :=
  sorry
```

```lean
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient
import Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.Deriv.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic

open Nat Finset Filter Set Classical

/-- Count of natural numbers n in {1, ..., N} with Ï†(n) < c Â· n -/
noncomputable def totientDensityCount (c : â„) (N : â„•) : â„• :=
  ((Finset.range (N + 1)).filter (fun n => 0 < n âˆ§ (Nat.totient n : â„) < c * â†‘n)).card

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #50:
Schoenberg proved that for every c âˆˆ [0,1] the natural density of
{n âˆˆ â„• : Ï†(n) < cn} exists. Let this density be denoted by f(c).
Is it true that there are no x such that f'(x) exists and is positive?

ErdÅ‘s proved the distribution function f is purely singular.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_50_conjecture :
    âˆ€ f : â„ â†’ â„,
      (âˆ€ c âˆˆ Icc (0 : â„) 1,
        Tendsto (fun N : â„• => (totientDensityCount c N : â„) / â†‘N) atTop (nhds (f c))) â†’
      âˆ€ x d : â„, HasDerivAt f d x â†’ d â‰¤ 0 :=
  sorry
```

```lean
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Archimedean
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat

open Classical Finset BigOperators

noncomputable section

/-- The sumset A + B: the set of all a + b with a âˆˆ A, b âˆˆ B. -/
def sumset35 (A B : Set â„•) : Set â„• := {n : â„• | âˆƒ a âˆˆ A, âˆƒ b âˆˆ B, n = a + b}

/-- Schnirelmann density of a set A âŠ† â„•:
    d_s(A) = inf_{N â‰¥ 1} |A âˆ© {1, â€¦, N}| / N -/
noncomputable def schnirelmannDensity (A : Set â„•) : â„ :=
  sInf {x : â„ | âˆƒ N : â„•, N â‰¥ 1 âˆ§ x = ((Icc 1 N).filter (Â· âˆˆ A)).card / (N : â„)}

/-- A set B âŠ† â„• is an additive basis of order k if every natural number
    can be written as a sum of exactly k elements from B (with repetition).
    Since 0 âˆˆ B is assumed separately, "exactly k" is equivalent to "at most k". -/
def IsAdditiveBasis35 (B : Set â„•) (k : â„•) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ n : â„•, âˆƒ f : Fin k â†’ â„•, (âˆ€ i, f i âˆˆ B) âˆ§ âˆ‘ i, f i = n

/--
**ErdÅ‘s Problem #35** (Proved):

Let B âŠ† â„• be an additive basis of order k with 0 âˆˆ B. Is it true that for every
A âŠ† â„• we have d_s(A + B) â‰¥ Î± + Î±(1 - Î±)/k, where Î± = d_s(A) is the
Schnirelmann density?

This was proved by PlÃ¼nnecke [Pl70], who showed the stronger inequality
d_s(A + B) â‰¥ Î±^{1-1/k}, as observed by Ruzsa.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_35
    (A B : Set â„•) (k : â„•) (hk : k â‰¥ 1)
    (hB : IsAdditiveBasis35 B k) (h0 : (0 : â„•) âˆˆ B) :
    let Î± := schnirelmannDensity A
    schnirelmannDensity (sumset35 A B) â‰¥ Î± + Î± * (1 - Î±) / (k : â„) :=
  sorry

end
```

```lean
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Ordinal

open Ordinal Cardinal

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #70

Let ğ”  be the cardinality of the continuum, Î² be any countable ordinal, and
2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰. Is it true that ğ”  â†’ (Î², n)Â²â‚ƒ?

That is, for every 2-coloring of the 3-element increasing sequences of
ordinals below ğ” , there is either a homogeneous set of order type Î² for
one color, or a homogeneous set of size n for the other color.

ErdÅ‘s and Rado proved that ğ”  â†’ (Ï‰ + n, 4)Â²â‚ƒ for any 2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰.

Tags: graph theory, ramsey theory, set theory
-/

/-- The ordinal partition relation `Î± â†’ (Î², Î³)Â²â‚ƒ`:
for every 2-coloring of increasing triples from ordinals below `Î±`,
there is either a homogeneous set of order type `Î²` for color 0,
or a homogeneous set of order type `Î³` for color 1.

A homogeneous set of order type `Î´` is given by a strictly increasing
function `g` mapping ordinals below `Î´` to ordinals below `Î±`, such that
all increasing triples in the image of `g` receive the same color. -/
def OrdinalPartition3_2 (Î± Î² Î³ : Ordinal) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ f : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal â†’ Ordinal â†’ Fin 2,
    (âˆƒ g : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal,
      (âˆ€ i j, i < Î² â†’ j < Î² â†’ i < j â†’ g i < g j) âˆ§
      (âˆ€ i, i < Î² â†’ g i < Î±) âˆ§
      âˆ€ i j k, i < j â†’ j < k â†’ k < Î² â†’ f (g i) (g j) (g k) = 0) âˆ¨
    (âˆƒ g : Ordinal â†’ Ordinal,
      (âˆ€ i j, i < Î³ â†’ j < Î³ â†’ i < j â†’ g i < g j) âˆ§
      (âˆ€ i, i < Î³ â†’ g i < Î±) âˆ§
      âˆ€ i j k, i < j â†’ j < k â†’ k < Î³ â†’ f (g i) (g j) (g k) = 1)

/--
**ErdÅ‘s Problem #70** [Er87]:

Let ğ”  be the cardinality of the continuum (viewed as an initial ordinal),
Î² be any countable ordinal, and 2 â‰¤ n < Ï‰. Is it true that ğ”  â†’ (Î², n)Â²â‚ƒ?
-/
theorem erdos_problem_70 (Î² : Ordinal) (hÎ² : Î².card â‰¤ â„µâ‚€)
    (n : â„•) (hn : 2 â‰¤ n) :
    OrdinalPartition3_2 (Cardinal.continuum.ord) Î² (â†‘n) :=
  sorry

end
```

**File 7: /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/79.lean** (Graph Theory - Ramsey Theory)
```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic

open SimpleGraph

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #79

We say G is *Ramsey size linear* if R(G,H) â‰ª m for all graphs H with m edges
and no isolated vertices.

Are there infinitely many graphs G which are not Ramsey size linear but such
that all of its proper subgraphs are?

Asked by ErdÅ‘s, Faudree, Rousseau, and Schelp [EFRS93].
Proved by Wigderson [Wi24]. Kâ‚„ is the only explicitly known example.
-/

/-- `IsSubgraphOf H G` means H is isomorphic to a subgraph of G: there exists an
    injection from V(H) to V(G) that preserves adjacency. -/
def IsSubgraphOf {Î± Î² : Type*} (H : SimpleGraph Î±) (G : SimpleGraph Î²) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ f : Î± â†’ Î², Function.Injective f âˆ§ âˆ€ u v, H.Adj u v â†’ G.Adj (f u) (f v)

/-- The Ramsey property: every 2-coloring of K_n contains G in one color or H in the
    other. A 2-coloring of K_n is a graph S on Fin n; one color class is S and the
    other is Sá¶œ (the complement). -/
def RamseyProp {p q : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q))
    (n : â„•) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ S : SimpleGraph (Fin n), IsSubgraphOf G S âˆ¨ IsSubgraphOf H Sá¶œ

/-- A graph has no isolated vertices if every vertex has at least one neighbor. -/
def NoIsolatedVertices {q : â„•} (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ v : Fin q, âˆƒ w : Fin q, H.Adj v w

/-- A graph G is Ramsey size linear if there exists C > 0 such that for every graph H
    with no isolated vertices, the Ramsey property R(G,H) holds at some n â‰¤ C Â· |E(H)|. -/
def IsRamseySizeLinear {p : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)) : Prop :=
  âˆƒ C : â„, C > 0 âˆ§ âˆ€ (q : â„•) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)) [DecidableRel H.Adj],
    NoIsolatedVertices H â†’
    âˆƒ n : â„•, (n : â„) â‰¤ C * (H.edgeFinset.card : â„) âˆ§ RamseyProp G H n

/-- **ErdÅ‘s Problem #79**: There exist infinitely many graphs which are not Ramsey
    size linear but all of whose proper subgraphs are. A graph H is a proper subgraph
    of G if H embeds into G (as a subgraph) but G does not embed into H. -/
theorem erdos_conjecture_79 :
    âˆ€ N : â„•, âˆƒ (p : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin p)),
      p â‰¥ N âˆ§
      Â¬ IsRamseySizeLinear G âˆ§
      âˆ€ (q : â„•) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin q)),
        IsSubgraphOf H G â†’
        Â¬ IsSubgraphOf G H â†’
        IsRamseySizeLinear H := by
  sorry
```

```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Floor.Defs

open SimpleGraph Finset Real

/-- Count edges in the induced subgraph on vertex set S:
    the number of pairs {u, v} with u, v âˆˆ S, u < v, and G.Adj u v. -/
def inducedEdgeCount {n : â„•} (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    (S : Finset (Fin n)) : â„• :=
  ((S Ã—Ë¢ S).filter (fun p => p.1 < p.2 âˆ§ G.Adj p.1 p.2)).card

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #88 (Proved by Kwan, Sah, Sauermann, Sawhney [KSSS22]):
For any Îµ > 0 there exists Î´ = Î´(Îµ) > 0 such that if G is a graph on n vertices
with no independent set or clique of size â‰¥ Îµ log n then G contains an induced
subgraph with exactly m edges for all m â‰¤ Î´nÂ².

Conjectured by ErdÅ‘s and McKay.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_88 :
    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, Îµ > 0 â†’
      âˆƒ Î´ : â„, Î´ > 0 âˆ§
        âˆ€ (n : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) (h : DecidableRel G.Adj),
          haveI := h
          G.CliqueFree âŒˆÎµ * Real.log nâŒ‰â‚Š â†’
          Gá¶œ.CliqueFree âŒˆÎµ * Real.log nâŒ‰â‚Š â†’
          âˆ€ m : â„•, (m : â„) â‰¤ Î´ * (n : â„) ^ 2 â†’
            âˆƒ S : Finset (Fin n), inducedEdgeCount G S = m :=
  sorry
```
